column13: One of the absolute best games I've ever played in my entire freakin life. Seriously.
column14:
I pulled over 125 hours of solid gameplay with this one. I played it every day for weeks, day and night, whenever I had free time. You can say that I was addicted, because I WAS--I couldn't put this game down. It is one of my all-time favorite games. I bought it on a whim; I got my Vita cause, why not get one? I needed games for it, got a few random ones, including P4:G. At that point, I'd never played a Persona game in my life, I had no idea what the games were like, either. I wasn't a fan of turn based combat and "comic booky" like dialogue--I was used to a lot of fluid motion and action, like Kingdom Hearts sorta. This game was entirely different for me, and changed my gaming life forever!! It opened so many doors and gave me such a broader array of games to enjoy! I will honestly say that this game was more than a game, it was an EXPERIENCE. An experience full of tears, racing heartbeats, sweaty hands, head scratching, cursing, laughing, embarrassment and shock: I LIVED in this game.

The story: 10/10. Without going into much detail, the story is incredibly dynamic and in a way, realistic. Of course the evens that happened in the game could probably never happen for real, but it was REAL in the game. I actually felt scared for the city, and scared for the people. You get this sense of dread and being trapped and having to delve deep within yourself to pull out the hero inside, and save everyone. The game hurts, it can hurt you emotionally--you deeply feel for everyone involved. A spoiler free synopsis is that people are being killed mysteriously. You've got to go to another world to uncover the truths about the murders and disappearances before it's too late. And that's exactly what you'll be driven to do, too! And at the same time, you've got to balance saving the world with being student--studying, building skills, etc. You can have jobs, hobbies, and most importantly, you've got to build up your social skills and make new friends. This was alesson in real life for me as I ironically shut myself in all day to play this game, I realized that I need to actually work on my real life as hard as I work on my life in the game! See I told you: this game is an experience.

The characters: 11/10. The story follows eight heroes, all meticulously and wonderfully dynamic in their own ways--as are all of the characters you encounter in the game. Every single character is unique and has their own story to tell, their own feelings and struggles, and their own life for the overall Persona experience. Not a single PERSON in this game is flat. And I mean it. The characters in this game are like your real friends, you see them, hang out with them, go to movies with them, get into trouble with them, and so on. You feel for them, and fear for them as well. And as you build your social circle, you understand that that random person sitting on a bench could teach you a real lesson in life. Nearly everyone in this game is important: be sure to talk to as many people as you can!

The gameplay: 10/10. As a person who would have told you that turn-based combat is for chumps, I can bravely admit that I was ignorant and borderline stupid to believe that!! The combat is AMAZING. It is quite similar to the other Persona games (I'm playing through P3: FES as we speak) so if you've played the previous ones, you've got a good understanding of how it works. I will say that I have never played P4, so I'm not sure of how similar P4:G is to that one, in terms of gameplay. But there are some differences from P3 to P4:G, and the differences are all MUCH, MUCH better! First off, you can use any of the 4 characters you can equip at a time, or you can use all 4. You can CONTROL your characters. That is a major annoyance in the gameplay of P3: FES; the characters oftentimes make incredibly stupid decisions and there's absolutely nothing I can do about it. You don't have that issue in P4:G, you are in control, IF you want to be. (when I fought lesser shadows I'd allow the computer to take over, but I'd control all my teammates when fighting bosses). Everyone has access to your inventory, so if you die, (YOU as in the main character of the game, who is untitled) your teammates can revive you (if you die in P3: FES it's GAME OVER). This allows the fights to go much more smoothly, because using your HUMAN brain you can use bufu (ice) against an enemy that is weak with ice, even if you don't have any Personas or items that have bufu (Use Teddie or Chie!) Another thing, being charmed in Persona is no longer a death sentence (being charmed is literally being CHARMED haha, where the enemy puts sort of a love spell on you and you heal the enemy and attack your teammates. It sucks!!) because you are able to control your teammates, you can give yourself or anyone else an item to "un-charm" them quickly, before you inflict too much damage. This is extremely important and useful because as I said before--being charmed in P3: FES is a death sentence--you actually have to wait until the spell wears off, that is the only way you can be dis-charmed. It is possible to have null-charm too, though.

And yes, Persona has it's very own arsenal of terminology for elements and other attacks. Ice (bufu), lightening (zio), fire (agi), wind (garu), and so on all have different names. You will quickly learn those other names, so don't be intimidated by having to learn new words.

Shuffle Time is also much better in Persona 4: Golden. Shuffle Time is when you fight the shadows in an awesome way haha, you are rewarded with some random cards. Some cards have Personas, some have other level ups and life and SP (MP in most other games) and so on. Most of the cards are beneficial to you. Shuffle Time is good cause you can choose what card (sometimes cardS) you want, (in P3: FES, the cards are literally shuffled [hence the name] and you gotta recall on your memory to get what you want).

There are also assists in P4:G (unsure if they are in the original Persona 4). Because you have 7 fighters to choose from, sometimes randomly a character that you don't have equipped can assist you and knock down enemies or something. It's always very fun and funny! Likewise, your teammates can work together and take down shadows--Chie and Yukiko have an awesome assist together. And your teammates can also do assists separately. My favorite is Chie's, where she literally kicks a random shadow completely off of the field, only to blink as a far distant star, Team Rocket style!

The fusion of Personas are simple--you can choose by arcana or level and so on. I usually chose by level, and it was as simple as pie.

Other than dungeon crawling (which is a large part of the game) the other gameplay is just as sweet. The dialogue is presented in text boxes and you just push X to "flip the page" kinda. The characters always speak so you can just wait until they finish, or just hit X and read yourself quickly (I loved the voice acting so I didn't mind hearing them talk!) There is third person roaming too, you can roam around your city and also in the dungeons in third person. You can build stuff, fish, read, catch bugs, and so on, all with their own set of controls, but they are all very simple to learn. ALL of the gameplay is simple, and effective.

Overall interest: 100/10. This game was like crack--it was so, SO addicting. I love every single microsecond of it too. I haven't played it since (finished it maybe a year or so ago, only now writing the review!) and I'm actually afraid to play it again, in fear that it will swallow my life once more. But, isn't that the best compliment you can give to a video game? Haha! P4:G is a masterpiece, it should go down in history of one of the best games of all times. It is no wonder that it tops the charts of nearly every "Best Vita Games" article you may read, and also no wonder thatit has 5 stars on Amazon. IT. IS. AMAZING. You can feel this game, you can be this game, you can make it your own.

Would I recommend it? Heck yes, I will! But be warned--and it SHOULD come with a warning label!! It will swallow you whole. And one more word of advice, which may be unclear to someone who hasn't beat the game but THEY should listen closest: pay attention to detail. Nearly EVERYONE you meet is important. ASK QUESTIONS in the game, especially so near the end. There are multiple endings of this game: a good one, a bad one, and the Golden Ending. In order to get the Golden Ending, ASK QUESTIONS.

Overall, one of the best darn games I've ever played. Get it.

The review below mine is brilliantly said, and I can't add much more.  Just a confirmation that yes, this game is exactly the same as the Super NES version graphically, and the only difference between the PC/PS version are the addition of cutscenes in the beginning of each of the 8 Maverick hunter stages, as well as longer cutscenes in the beginning and end of the game.  Most of them are forgettable, overly cutesy and appear out of place for those who know the Super NES version very well.  I've never liked cutscenes in Mega Man games to be honest, but using them is the route the series would eventually go.    The other really big change are the remixed theme songs.  They totally messed up Neon Tiger and Tunnel Rhino's themes- they no longer have that heavy adrenaline-rushing punch.  Other themes like Blast Hornet and Toxic Seahorse aren't any better, but they're still decent.  I prefer the heavy rocking music of the Super NES version by a longshot.  Otherwise, this is *exactly* the same game as the Super NES version.  I understand the Super NES version is like 200 bucks now (which is really silly by the way) but that would be the better version to get.  I think there might be a second reason Mega Man X3 on the Super NES is so expensive.  Capcom releasing so few copies is one reason for the price spike of course, but if you've noticed the price really jumped up when that Mega Man X Anniversary collection came out.  Considering that game features the PC/PS version with the remixed theme songs and cutscenes, it's no wonder the Super NES version has become so valuable and expensive.  Bad decision in my opinion to include the PC/PS version on the Anniversary collection.

- Awkward placement of master volume
- Chat/Game volume mixer commonly accidentally pushed (ie, against couch cushion)
- Low quality, cheap stand
- Awkward, "tinny", compressed sounding low quality mic (I'd read this in other people's reviews. TRUST THEM! I began being known as "The Fighter Pilot" in my clan!)
- Only 3 marginally different EQs
- Absolutely TERRIBLE customer service from Astro
- The headset out of nowhere "popping"/crackling/filling with static until my controller gets overwhelmed and disconnects.

The last one was the kicker!! I can't have my controller and chat randomly disconnecting!! It is apparently a wide spread issue that when your controllers batteries drop below 75% (give or take) the lowering amount of power sends the headset into crazy static that shut downs the controller/chat briefly. And trust me, it always seemed to happen in the most intense gaming moments!! Exchanged my headset twice at the stores advice that I must have just got a dud. Then on the third one tried to troubleshoot. Astro will suggest that it's YOUR controller (hence the two controllers I mentioned), they'll suggest it's your wifi signal interfering with the headset (disabled router's broadcast and hard wired, to no avail), but the only confirmed work around I found was keeping your controller connected with a plug and play kit while you game. Kind of defeats the purpose of a WIRELESS headset wouldn't you agree? Give it a quick search! I wish I'd known about this headset's disconnecting controller problems before I bought it.

Believe me, I wanted to love this headset! The sound quality itself was some of the best I've heard from a headset! And if you're a completely single player gamer who only games for short amounts of time between controller charges, or with their controller always charging, then I'd feel comfortable recommending the A50. But if you love to chat as much as you love good sound quality, and don't want your controller constantly disconnecting, your $$$ is better spent elsewhere. Most expensive does NOT always equal best.

Sony's PlayStation TV is a great device if you know what you are getting. If you are getting this to use Remote Play from you PlayStation 4 or to play supported PlayStation Vita games, you will not regret this purchase. While it would have made sense for Sony to push the PlayStation TV as a streaming media player as well as micro-console, they did not. While it works with some streaming apps, there are some major omissions such as Netflix, therefore, do not buy this expecting it to replace an Apple TV or Roku even on a secondary TV.

Pros:
- Works with many PlayStation Vita games.
- Remote Play from PlayStation 4.
- Supports DualShock 3 or DualShock 4 controller.
- Very affordable after price reduction.

Cons:
- Not all PlayStation Vita games are supported by PlayStation TV.
- Due to lack of Netflix support among others, this device is a micro-console and nothing more.

This is a must have if you want to use you PlayStation 4 in multiple rooms without having to unplug and physically move it. This is also great if you want the ability to play PlayStation Vita exclusives, without having to pay $200. Just be aware not all games are supported.

First of all, to echo a couple of the other comments, if the price is listed at $199 this is wrong, and probably due to a private seller scalping; I picked up my Revo K101 Plus (the original white model, although the hardware is identical) direct from the manufacturer for around $70 (approx. Â£45) earlier in the year - and that was delivered to the UK.

Let's keep this brief, because you are anything like me there are certain things that you want to know.

1. It's a hardware clone, not an emulator. This means that it is 99% compatible with any GBA carts or accessories that you might have. The only notable exception is the GBA wireless adapter, and that's only because there's nowhere for it to clip on to the console (something that the manufacturer might want to consider looking into).

2. Being a hardware clone, it plays titles perfectly with 100% accurate image and sound. The screen's aspect ratio is a little different, so by default it displays a little vertically stretched, but if you don't mind slight black borders you can switch it to native using the hotkeys.

3. The screen is backlit and sharp, comparable to the GB Micro (albeit larger) or the AGS-101.

4. Battery life is around 4 - 5 hours, depending on your brightness setting. The unit features a rechargeable lith-ion battery and charges via bog-standard mini-USB cable (not micro). A standard USB plug (like the ones supplied with iOS/Android devices or tablets, or something like the Kindle) charges it fine. That means NO PROPRIETARY CABLES (hooray!).

5. Yes, you can load ROMS. Yes, it is supplied with the add-on to allow you to do this (the K-Card cartridge). The K-Card requires a micro-USB card (also supplied, a 2GB card) for ROM-loading. I have tested up to 16GB class 10 with no read/write issues. ROMS play no differently to original carts.

6. No, it won't play original GB or GBC carts from cartridge, but it WILL play them from ROM. You can load NES ROMs too.

This has genuinely become my go-to unit for playing GBA games (in particular Pokémon, naturally), especially since my AGS-101 has a faulty screen and my Micro gives me a headache after a while!

column13: It's not horrible, but it's still substandard.
column14:
I waited almost a full year since the game's release to write this, hoping it'd get better within that time.

The game has more stuff, but overall, it hasn't gotten much better at all. Sims 4 feels like it should've been between Sims 1 and Sims 2. Even Sims 1 has a feature Sims 4 lacks. I've heard some dope say this game is more suited for those white liked Sims 2 and not Sims 3, but I've got to disagree with that. I have a huge amount of fun with Sims 2 and Sims 4 does not compare at all to it. It doesn't even come close and I don't it ever will be able to.

Sims 4 seems like it's hugely YA-oriented. Much of the game is more about single, young adults partying than anything else. There isn't much available for children to do. A playground consists of only a set of monkey bars and a jungle gym. That's it. Teenagers may as well be adults in high school. That's about the only thing unique to them. Family play is sorely lacking and while the lack of toddlers plays a big part in that, it's also how there's barely anything to make up for it. Parents may as well just be around so kids have people to talk to. I thought infants couldn't get any more restrained when they were bundled up in Sims 3, but Sims 4 confines them to the cradle. They're not bundles anymore, but it doesn't matter. They may as well be since they're stuck in the cradle until the end of their infancy.

I got over not having the open world. What I didn't get over is how much they restricted the worlds we did get. Not only are Sims 4's worlds ridiculously tiny (one of which from the expansion pack only has a grand total of FOUR lots available; pitiful), but lots are permanent as they're already set. Lots can't be added, removed, or rotated like in previous games. That might not be so bad if not for the fact the each world only has around 20 lots. Even Sims 2 was capable of having more lots than that in one world. The worlds cannot be edited either, so basically, you're stuck with how they are, whether you like it or not. I'm not even going to get into the world maps, which look like they were designed by a group of first-grade children.

Emotions, which were made a very big deal prior to the game's release, have little impact on the gameplay over all. The emotional system is also very easy to manipulate. column6: Dungeon Travelers 2: The Royal Library & the Monster Seal - PlayStation Vita
column14: I had hoped that eventually someone would take a chance and localize the original To Heart 2: Dungeon Travelers, in which the cast of the well-known visual novel To Heart 2 found themselves thrust in a dungeon crawling RPG.  That unfortunately never happened, so I was surprised when Atlus announced they'd be localizing its sequel, this game.  In the game, the protagonist Fried is a Libra in training.  Libras are magic users who specialize in sealing away dangerous monsters. Unfortunately they generally don't have much in the way of combat skills, and so to do their job they need to be supported by a party of other characters.  Since Alisia and Melvy, a couple of Fried's friends from the academy happen to be hanging around when the countryside around the royal library is hit with an outbreak of monsters, we have a reason to go dungeon-crawling.  The gameplay is quite similar to games such as [[ASIN:B000IOM45C Etrian Odyssey - Nintendo DS]] and [[ASIN:B001Q933P8 Class of Heroes - Sony PSP]].  The royal library serves as a home base where the characters can recuperate when not exploring.  In an interesting little twist, the characters can rest for free at the library, so there are no worries about spending all the proceeds of a dungeon exploration on healing at an inn.  As the game progresses, Fried will meet plenty of new allies; each of his new allies has a basic class (fighter, magic user, maid, etc.), but as the characters level up, they can branch out into more advanced versions of that basic class.  And of course, the game's hook is that most of the monsters encountered in the dungeons are standard RPG beasts (ghosts, werewolves, etc.) anthropomorphized as moe anime-style characters.  The bosses (or "mutants") are styled in the same way, and generally after beating the boss the player is treated to a visual-novel type scene where the boss' clothes have been shredded or the boss is depicted in a highly suggestive manner.  Considering this game's visual novel origins, this shouldn't be too surprising, but be advised there will be some pretty suggestive stuff lurking.  I'm not sure the "M" rating is warranted, but neither is that rating totally out of line.  That said, you might expect a light and fluffy game where outside of the cutscenes and moe characters, there's not much underneath.  However, there's a pretty deep and challenging RPG modulo all of the fan-pandering.  While the first dungeon is not much of a challenge, after that point there is a difficulty spike and the game is not afraid to punish the player if they wander into a encounter unprepared. The player will no doubt find themselves scrambling out of the dungeon with a decimated party from time to time, and being underleveled during a boss fight can easily culminate in a game over. Fortunately, a little bit of grinding for an extra level or two will usually equalize the playing field.  So overall, this game ended up being exactly what I was looking for-a solid RPG with some nice anime style eye candy.  The character and monster designs are very attractive, there's a solid and challenging game, and each character class has a pretty wide range of skills which can be leveled up as the player desires.  That said, there are a few definite flaws in the game as well.  The highly-suggestive nature of some of the cutscenes and some of the monster designs may put off some players, most of the characters are pretty stock archetypes (Fried could have stepped out of the lead role of a harem anime, and Alisia is a standard "old friend" of the protagonist for example), and the mapping system leaves a bit to be desired.  Some of the dungeon maps are quite large, and there are two map views available.  Unfortunately, the large area of some of the dungeons means that when the map is zoomed-out, the player could find themselves squinting and straining to see how to navigate from point A to B while the zoomed-in map doesn't give an adequate overall view of the layout.  Additionally, the map marks the location of treasures, but it would have been nice to be able to mark certain points on the map to visit later (to make a note of a boss location for example).  Overall, however, if you like dungeon crawlers and cute anime girls, this is probably a Vita title you should consider acquiring.

column13: Another winner in the Etrian Odyssey series, with options to make it a great fit for veterans and newcomers alike
column14:
The latest in the Etrian Odyssey (EO) dungeon exploration/role-playing series, EO2 Untold is generally the most refined and adaptable game in the series to date. Adaptability comes in the form of dozens of tweakable gameplay options, new Story and Classic modes, difficulty levels, and even optional DLC if so inclined. One can indulge in the harder difficulty and manual mapping of dungeons that the series became famous for or take a more relaxed approach with lower difficulty and auto-mapping.

Much effort has been expended in creating a new Story mode for this revisiting of the older EO2 (as was done in the first EO Untold). Note that this series has always had a basic storyline, but the new Untold variants add another layer to them with predefined characters (versus blank slates in Classic), solid voice acting, and a new dungeon. EO2 Untold pulls ahead of the earlier Untold game by having a more intuitive Grimoire system and a pleasant restaurant side-game that allows one to decipher recipes for stat boosts. The Grimoire system remains a random system of earning transferrable character and enemy skills for customization, but has been smartly simplified.

The story and characters themselves are very entertaining, especially the duo of Bertrand and Chloe. Fortunately, there are multiple save slots available to revisit story points easily or keep separate files for both Story and Classic playthroughs.

On a couple tracks you end up in front halfway thru which gets kind of boring, but most others you must work for a top 5. You may wan't to tweak steering assistance to 15 percent or more. I have no problems spinning out or keeping control of the car when nudging into the back or side of opponents. I was surprised how easy it is to control the car in Simulation with a gamepad which has rough choppy steering and acceleration.

I'm running the game on a Windows 7 64 bit system with a low end NVidia GeForce GT 220 Graphics Card. Everything loaded and plays fine. I have all the Graphics options turned up all the way and there is no lag and it looks great.

It's a quality product. I was concerned because some of the reviews were negative. The whole thing looks really stretched out to me in the pictures but it's actually really cool looking in person. The buttons don't squeak (someone made a big deal about that). The stick has a nice "broken in" feel. There's enough room on the platform for your left hand and your right hand rests on the beveled edge. I only played for an hour, and it was comfortable enough not to concern myself with thinking about it! There's mats on the bottom of it of a foamy material. should help anchor to a table.

Play tests:
- SF2 (PC) roundhouse wouldn't map correctly, could be specific to my set up. I didn't get hung up on it though, as I was just play testing punch latency and specials. Everything was acceptable. Light punches came out at the same timing from the stick as the keyboard. If there's a PC latency I couldn't see it in that play test. Tested Ken, fireballs were tight, Tetsumaki combos came out easy, shoryuken on reaction. Negative edge stuff was seamless. I'm a little rusty on SF but it seemed really good for the PC.

- Pac-Man (PC, PS3 (namco museum)) I didn't overshoot any turns, played for 10 minutes or so. Stick worked fine.

- Capcom vs SNK 2 (PS3 - but it's the PS2 version) works great. I played the computer but the matches went well. I nailed combos, was able to operate on reaction, spacing was fine for me. Blanka, Honda, Ken - able to do supers without compromise. Play seemed unhindered.

- Tekken Revolution - no problem in practice mode. Was able to nail Paul's sways/ punch sways (df+1 b...). Just frame was fine. everything seemed on point. Online matches were a different story! The stick has no control over lag ;)

I really thought about spending the extra bucks for the madkatz stick. I have the SF4 stick for 360 and like it. So far, I would put the RAP4 on that level of quality, just different design (different buttons, different stick feel, good heft but less mass overall). I saved $50 over the current madkatz models and got a great stick. If, after heavy play I learn something important, I'll update the review.

column13: Worth the PS4 upgrade, if you're a fan of the game or just want to pretend you're a pirate.
column14:
I just wanted to comment that while this is a PS3 game ported to the PS4 system, it seems one of your better, more worthwhile ports in terms of graphics quality. Unlike some PS3 to PS4 game ports that I've played, namely The Last of Us, the upgrade in graphics quality doesn't feel as much like you're still playing a PS3 game. The video is more stable and seems rendered at higher resolution, making the game feel almost new again, or at least not a huge step back, if you've already acclimated to the better experience of the PS4. Don't set your expectations too high, as this definitely isn't as visually impressive as the best the PS4 has to offer. But, unlike The Last of Us, I wasn't disappointed with the game visually. It also seems to take advantage of some other next generation perks too, like loading speeds, if my memory is true.

As for the game, I've played all of the AC games to date, and completed all but the very first. I've never been fond of the franchises story, but the gameplay is fantastic and the story can virtually be ignored when focused on the quests, especially after the single-player campaign has completed and you're left to roam the open seas in search of plunder and buried treasure. And if you're in Pirates of the Caribbean withdraw, while waiting for the next sequel or if you like the concept of playing an open world game as a romanticized old-world pirate, this is the best I've come across.

column13: Dragon Age II is the best game in the series
column14:
I don't care what anyone says. Dragon Age II is the best game in the series. It's better than Origins and Inquisition. Don't get me wrong, I liked Origins and Inquisition, but neither of them are as good as Dragon Age II.

What makes Dragon Age II unique is that the player character isn't trying to save the world. They're trying to protect themselves and the people they care about, and they don't always succeed. It does a good job demonstrating that sometimes loss is inevitable; sometimes people can't be saved, from circumstances or from themselves. It also does a good job portraying characters realistically; their personalities and opinions are complex and influenced by their unique circumstances, and aren't necessarily always good or strong.

I could talk about Dragon Age II and its extraordinary characters forever. Beyond that, the quests are very interesting; the combat is fun and fast paced (and can be challenging, especially on higher difficulties); the graphics are very good for a game its age, and the sound track is absolutely gorgeous.

This game made me feel in ways other games couldn't. My words can't do it justice. I really recommend experiencing it for yourself.

Destiny is one of those games that just didn't live up to the hype. Being a Bungie game, it's already going to have alot of hype around it. The trailers, screenshot, teasers, even the fact that Paul McCartney worked with Marty O'Donnell and Michael Salvatori to make the soundtrack spawned alot of hype. But the game came out, and alot of people were dissapointed (including me). It's visually very impressive, beautiful graphics, dynamic skyboxes, cool level and character design, and neat weapons. It feels like Halo, but with more common FPS mechanics added in. The core of the game is really fun, but there's little to no content, besides DLC. The campaign (again, without DLC) will probably take you under 3 hours to beat, depending on skill level. Every other mission, your AI helper, your Ghost, he examines a computer, tries to gain access, and trips the alarm, and then from there, it becomes survival, defending him from wave after wave of enemies.The only story is found in these collectibles called "Grimoire cards" that tell bits of the lore. Gameplay is really, REALLY fun, but there isnt enough content to really enjoy it. But, besides the campaign, there are these Patrol missions on each planet, where you just run around for however long, finding and killing enemies and doing little missions. Anyone who plays this game (like me) will play for 6 hours at a time, then complain about it.
